lines.text: I don't think I want to know a six-year-old who isn't a dreamer, or a sillyheart. And I sure don't want to know one who takes their student career seriously. I don't have a college degree. I don't even have a job. But I know a good kid when I see one. Because they're ALL good kids, until dried-out, brain-dead skags like you drag them down and convince them they're no good. You so much as scowl at my niece, or any other kid in this school, and I hear about it, and I'm coming looking for you!
[of Anita's mole]
Take this quarter, go downtown, and have a rat gnaw that thing off your face! Good day to you, madam.
[Buck's beat up old car pulls up]

[sarcastic]
Ever hear of a tune up? Hee hee hee hee hee.

[also sarcastic]
Ah, heh heh heh. Ever hear of a ritual killing? Ah, heh heh heh heh heh!
I don't get it.

[serious tone]
You gnaw on her face in public like that again and you'll be one. Ah, heh heh heh heh!
Well, well, well, they certainly are scraping the bottom of the barrel for cheerleaders these days.
What are you doing here?
We were just driving by to get some ice cream. Thought you might like to join us.
I said I would be home at 10. It's not even 9!

Who said anything about that? I thought you might like to join us for some ice cream. Maybe your Bug here can join us. We can talk about burying the hatchet. You know what a hatchet is, don't you, Bug?
It's an ax?
Sort of, yeah, yeah. I got one in my car if you'd like to see it.

[getting scared]
I'll pass.

Fair enough. I like to carry it, you never know when you're going to need it. A situation may come up say for example, someone has been drinking, and about to drive a loved one home... then I'd like to know I have it. Not to kill, no. Just to maim. Take a little off the shoulder. Swish! The elbow. Slash! Shave a little meat off the old kneecap. Fowap! Ooooo! You got both kneecaps? I like to keep mine razor sharp. Sharp enough you can shave with it. Why I've been known to circumcise a gnat. You're not a gnat are you, Bug? Wait a minute, bug, gnat. Is there a little similarity? Whoa, I think there is! Ha ha ha. You understand what I'm talking about? I don't think you do. I'll be right back. Heh heh heh heh.
[walks away]
I'm sorry.
Look, I think you'd better split. I don't exactly want him to go berserk with an ax on me.
He's all talk.
[Buck pulls out a small hatchet from his car]
Here it is! Come over, come on, I want to show it to you. Maybe later. Okay.
Where do you live?
In the city.
You have a house?
Apartment.
Own or rent?
Rent.
What do you do for a living?
Lots of things.
Where's your office?
I don't have one.
How come?
I don't need one.
Where's your wife?
Don't have one.
How come?
It's a long story.
You have kids?
No I don't.
How come?
It's an even longer story.
Are you my dad's brother?
What's your record for consecutive questions asked?
I'm your dad's brother alright.
You have much more hair in your nose than my dad.
How nice of you to notice.
I'm a kid that's my job.
The guy's a predator and you're his prey.
Really?
You bet.
And how would you know?
When I was his age, I was a guy zooming girls like you. Pretty face, good chip on your shoulder.
I recommend you stay out of my personal life!
Do your parents stay out of your personal life?
They don't know my personal life.
Have they met twiddle-dink?
His name is Bug.

[chuckles]
First or last?
First!
What's his last name, Spray?
You should talk, Buck!
[at a meeting with the assistant principal, who's got a big unsightly growth on her face]
I'm Anita Hoargarth.

[Staring at it]
I'm Buck Melanoma. Moley Russell's wart. Not her wart. Not her wart! I'm... I'm the wart. She's my tumor. My... my growth. My... uh, my pimple. I'm Uncle Wart. Just old Buck "Wart" Russell. That's what they call me, or Melanoma Head. They'll call me that. "Melanoma Head's coming." I'm s... uncle! Maisy Russell's uncle!

[is trying to make Tia go out bowling with him]
We've done the battle of the wills. The deck's stacked in my favor. You're just gonna lose again.
Try me.
How would you like to spend the next several nights wondering if your crazy, out-of-work, bum uncle will shave your head while you sleep? See you in the car.
What, did you have a few drinks this morning? Huh? Yeah, I think you did.
What are you? Mother Cabrini? You never touch the stuff?
No, no. It's just that I wouldn't be drinking if I was going to entertain some kids. You know?
I don't have to take this shit from you. You know who I am? In the field of local-live-home entertainment, I'm a god!
Get in your mouse, and get out of here.
Hey, you, let me tell you something you low-life-lying-four-flushing-sack-of-shit.
[Buck punches him, gets back up like an inflatable clown, Pooter groans, Buck punches him again]
What time do you want me to pick you up after school?
Don't bother! I'll get a ride with friends
No, I have my orders. What time?
Are you really this stupid? I said I would get a ride. I always get a ride.
Hey, I'll just call the school, find out what time, and meet you right here.
Go ahead, call the school. I won't be here.
00 okay?
Do you think she hates me?
With a passion.
Really? Do you think it's the hat?
No.
No? A lot of people hate this hat. It angers a lot of people, just the sight of it. Ah, I'll tell you a story about that on the way to school.
Did you brush your teeth?
Yeah. You can even feel my toothbrush.

You know, I have a friend who works at the crime lab at the police station. I could give him your toothbrush and he could run a test on it. To see if you actually brushed your teeth or just ran your toothbrush under the faucet.
[Miles imagines hearing sirens, Buck leaves]
If that's true, we're gonna really have to start brushing our teeth.

[struggling to open the washing machine]
Do I have to talk dirty to you? Come on! Open up for daddy! I'm gonna shove a load into you! Here we go! Come on, it's nice and easy. Aaah! Come on, here we go! Ah! Take that! Take that! Come on! You don't want the crowbar, do you? Come on! Open up! Ugh! I'm gonna shove my load into you whether you like it or not!

[struggles to pick a hissing, fighting cat up out of the bushes]
Come on.
[takes it into the house]
Hey who left the cat out?
We don't have a cat.

[takes the cat back out]
Shoo.
[Miles is gawking at his birthday breakfast]
You should see the toast. I couldn't even get it through the door.
Uncle Buck?
Yeah?
Got a minute?
I got lots of minutes.
Now that everything's okay with my grandfather, I want to go out tomorrow night.
You can go crazy after I leave. Until then, I'm not letting you out.

[getting angry]
You just can't find any way to be cool can you?
You mean easy? No.
I mean decent!
You mean blind!
Who are you trying to score points with? My parents? How many times have they had you over here since we moved? Try none until they went up Shit Creek and got stuck!

[looking frustrated]
Get used on your parents' time.
Are you crazy?
I can be.
You could have taken his head off!
Yeah, but would he notice?
Does anybody have a special story to tell the class about something that happened this week?
[Maisy raises her hand]
Maisy?
My uncle was micro waving our socks and the dog threw up on the couch for an hour.
Honest?
Mm-Hmm.
Why was your uncle micro waving your socks?
He can't get the goddamn washing machine to work.
Blasphemer!

[eating Chinese take out]
This is such a wonderful dinner, Mother. How do you find the time?
You know there's uh, one family charity case who loves you very much.

[crying]
I'm sorry.
Hey, come on. Nothing to be sorry about. I'm just glad I got a chance to know you again.
How many times a day does the dog eat?
How many times do you think?
I don't know, four or five.
He eats once a day.
Do have any idea how embarrassing this is? You driving me up to my school where everyone can see you? I can't believe I'm related to you.
You just get that big stick out of your keester young lady, and we'll get along just fine.
Can I ask you a personal question?
Sure.
Did you ever have anyone embarrass you like this?
[a very long pause as Buck glances up, then down, and side to side trying to remember and contemplating Tia's question until he makes eye contact with her again]
No.
I don't know why we need boys at all. They're so loud.

[Off screen]
Shut up!
Shut up, yourself!
We need boys, so they can grow up, get married, and turn into shadows.

[On the way to his brother's]
Oh boy, those kids. I haven't seen those kids in a while. Tia's gotta be nine. Nine, maybe ten. Oh boy. And the two new ones. They're uh Larry and uh. Larry and uh. Uh Betsy. Betsy, uh Jennifer. Jennifer. Larry and Jennifer. Oh boy.
Marcie Dahlgren-Frost. Dahlgren is my maiden name, Frost is my married name. I'm single again, but I never bothered to remove the Frost. And I get compliments on the hyphen.

[inquiring about the health of Bob's father-in-law]
Her dad?
Hard to say.
Oh, those medical terms eh?
Hey, I stopped smoking cigarettes.
Oh, good.

Isn't that something? I'm on to cigars now. I'm on to a five-year plan. I eliminated cigarettes, then I go to cigars, then I go to pipes, then I go to chewing tobacco, then I'm on to that nicotine gum.
Holy smokes!
[turns to Tia and whispers]
He's cooking our garbage!

[into the phone]
Hey, Bobby we should really get together sometime. I haven't been over at the new house since you moved. By the way, I want to apologize for last year at your old house about those bushes. I had no idea they all would catch on fire like that. You were right. I should never have put the barbeque grill that close.

[dancing to Young MC's "Bust a Move"]
Hey, nice music! Who is that, the Grass Roots? Just kidding, I know my music!
[Chanice is listening to an answering machine message from Buck]
I think about those two little dimples on your buns. Hahaha.
Dimples!
What do we call them? One, one was on the right was Lyndon and left was.
It's Johnson.
Johnson.
[Chanice laughs]
And then there was your boobs we did. Now, your boobs were Minnie and Mickey, I remember that because of Disney World. And Felix! Felix is what we called your.
[cut to the next scene, where a cat meows loudly]
[Miles and Maisey watch Tia make out with her boyfriend]
That's a pretty stupid thing to do during Flu season!
I'll bet she's getting the tongue!
Waiting for your sex?
Shut up!
Art Linkletter was right. Kids do say the God damndest things.
If my whole family moved away from me, I'd have a heart attack too.
Hey, Mom. Next time you take off in the middle of the night, why don't you hire a murderer to watch the house?
They have rent-a-shoes!
And rent-a-foot disease!
You always kick me around, I'm an American and I have rights.
Maisey, do I kick you around?
No, but you said 'shit' twice, only once that counts though.
Let the dog out.
Parcey!
[their dog Parcey emerges from the dryer]
Have a bad day today? It hurts when someone screws with your life, doesn't it?
What about Buck? I'm sure he'd be happy to watch the kids.
This is no time to discuss your brother. I don't want him here.
It's just a thought.
He isn't married. He doesn't have kids. He doesn't even work!
He's a little out there. But he's responsible, and he's family.

[while flipping a huge pancake]
Here's where we separate the men from the boys.
When Dad goes to New York, I'm going to take a week off work.
So you can interview new housekeepers?
I've had enough of your ugliness.
Oh really?
Mm-hmm. We're all just a little tired of the act.
For crying out loud! It's two a.m.!
Sorry Mr. Hatfield!
Who's gonna take care of us?
Mr. and Mrs. Neville.
Is that a joke?
You don't like the Nevilles?
Their dog's a ball sniffer.
Don't talk like that!
Mr. Neville yelled at Michael Larson because their dog was sniffing Michael's balls.
Don't use that word.
I don't know another word.
Well, I'm sure we can talk to Mr. Neville about the dog.
[first lines]
Get your bag off the table, people eat there.
People eat off of plates.
Don't give me any crap, Maizy.
...NUTS!
[snaps his fingers]
I wouldn't go in there with that hat
Thanks for the tip!
